title: Everyday English Conversation Practice | 30 Minutes English Listening

learningObjectives.title: Plan and execute a dining outing from hotel to restaurant
learningObjectives.description: Ask hotel staff for restaurant recommendations that match dietary preferences (e.g., vegetarian, spicy/non-spicy), understand menu items (daily special, soup vs. salad, sides, dressings), make a reservation, arrange a taxi, and confirm pickup time politely.

learningObjectives.title: Order coffee and handle payment and loyalty points
learningObjectives.description: Place multi-item takeout orders, choose sizes and milk options, ask health-related option questions, confirm totals with tax, pay by credit card, provide a phone number to add loyalty points, and follow pickup instructions.

learningObjectives.title: Complete basic bank counter transactions
learningObjectives.description: Interact with bank staff to deposit a check, use a bank card and enter a PIN, request and interpret an account balance receipt, and close the interaction using formal, polite language.

learningObjectives.title: Find, borrow, and discuss books (and related genres)
learningObjectives.description: Ask where sections are, follow directions, request and give book recommendations, discuss genres and author preferences (including female authors), check out with a library card, understand return dates, and politely clarify misunderstandings (e.g., when someone is not an employee).
skills: genre vocabulary (mystery, adventure, etc.) for books and films

learningObjectives.title: Shop for groceries and make smart quantity/price decisions
learningObjectives.description: Name common produce and dairy items, interpret sale offers (e.g., 10 for $3), choose appropriate quantities, handle fragile items, and express preferences and compromises when selecting products.

learningObjectives.title: Describe daily routines and give/accept advice for healthier habits
learningObjectives.description: Use present simple and time expressions to describe routines; discuss sleep, exercise, meals, and commuting; identify problems (e.g., late nights, skipping breakfast) and propose solutions using advice language (should/consider); practice Q&A repetition to build automatic speaking.
skills: giving and accepting advice (should, consider + gerund)
Q&A repetition for fluency and confidence

prerequisites.topic: CEFR A2 English foundations (grammar and core listening)
prerequisites.description: Students should comfortably understand and use present simple and present continuous for routines and current actions; form common questions (Wh- and yes/no) and short answers; use modals for requests and advice (can/could/may/would like/should); handle countable vs. uncountable nouns with quantifiers (some, any, much, many, a few, a little); and use comparatives/superlatives for choices (cheaper/healthier). They should follow slow-to-normal pace audio of everyday dialogues and extract key details (who, what, where, price, time).
suggestedResources: BBC Learning English – Lower Intermediate Listening: https://www.bbc.co.uk/learningenglish/english/course/lower-intermediate

prerequisites.topic: Numbers, time, money, and everyday units in English
prerequisites.description: Be able to tell and understand times (6:00, 7:45, noon, midnight), say and hear prices with decimals (e.g., $11.13), and read totals “after tax.” Understand common retail math and phrases: on sale, half price, total, receipt, change. Recognize quantities and packaging units: pot, cup, platter, side, bunch, bag, carton, piece, dozen. State and recognize phone numbers clearly for loyalty points. Know basic PIN security language and steps.

Know standard polite patterns used in hotels, restaurants, cafes, banks, and stores: Could you…? May I…? I’d like…, What do you recommend? Can you arrange…? That will be all. No, thank you. Understand how to accept/decline offers, ask for clarification (Sorry?/Could you repeat that?), and confirm details (So the return date is…; My total is…?). This supports making reservations, ordering, customizing drinks, paying by card, adding loyalty points, and asking staff for directions or help.
suggestedResources: BBC Learning English – How to be polite: https://www.bbc.co.uk/learningenglish/english/course/lower-intermediate/unit-7/session-1
ESL Fast – Conversations for beginners (service situations): https://eslfast.com/easy/

prerequisites.topic: Domain vocabulary for common public services and leisure
prerequisites.description: Recognize key words across the lesson contexts: hotel (reservation, staff, taxi), restaurant (menu, daily special, soup/salad, dressing, vegetarian, spicy, reservation), cafe (latte, iced, skim/soy/almond/oat milk, size names), bank (deposit, check/cheque, account balance, receipt, PIN, card reader), library/bookstore (borrow, return date/due date, library card, genre: fiction, mystery, adventure; author, recommendation), grocery (produce, fragile, unit names, on sale), cinema (genres: comedy, romance, action, horror, animated). Familiarity with these terms allows learners to follow and participate in dialogues without constant dictionary use.
suggestedResources: Quizlet – A2 Food & Drink / Shopping / Banking sets (search within Quizlet): https://quizlet.com
British Council – Vocabulary: Shopping and services: https://learnenglish.britishcouncil.org/vocabulary

prerequisites.topic: Daily routines, health habits, and giving advice
prerequisites.description: Know routine and health-related vocabulary (wake up, snooze, skip breakfast, fast food, hydrate, exercise, lift weights, ride a bike, pack lunch, hang out, get enough sleep). Be able to sequence events (first, then, after that, by [time]) and give/receive advice using should/shouldn’t and softeners (You could consider…, Maybe try…). Understand cause–effect links for habits (If you sleep earlier, you’ll have more energy).
suggestedResources: BBC Learning English – Giving advice (should/ought to): https://www.bbc.co.uk/learningenglish/english/course/lower-intermediate/unit-10/session-1

segments.title: From Hotel Concierge to Restaurant Seating
segments.content: Plan a lunch outing from the hotel: state dietary preferences, consider spicy/non-spicy options, choose a Japanese restaurant, make a reservation, and arrange a taxi. Arrive at the restaurant, request a table for two, receive menus, and order green tea.
keyTopics: greetings and small talk at a hotel

segments.title: Placing a Restaurant Order Confidently
segments.content: Navigate the full ordering process: ask about the daily special, clarify what is included (soup vs. salad), add a side salad with house dressing, compare choices (daily special vs. salmon platter), accept recommendations, and finalize the order.

segments.title: Finding and Borrowing the Right Book
segments.content: Ask for a book with action, locate the adventure section, request and evaluate recommendations (length, themes, characters), select a shorter, exciting title, and complete checkout with a library card and return-date reminder.

segments.title: Coffee Ordering, Payment, and Loyalty Points
segments.content: Order two iced drinks with size and milk choices, discuss healthier milk options, calculate a total with tax, pay by credit card, and add loyalty points using a phone number. Learn pickup logistics for takeout drinks.
keyTopics: milk options (regular, skim, fat-free, almond, soy, oat)

segments.title: Bank Counter Basics and Discussing Mystery Fiction
segments.content: Complete a bank transaction by depositing a check with card and PIN, then request and read an account balance receipt. Transition to a bookstore scenario to locate the fiction section, discuss mystery genre preferences, consider authors (Sherlock Holmes vs. Agatha Christie), and handle a polite misunderstanding with a fellow customer.

segments.title: Smart Grocery Shopping and Choosing Movie Genres
segments.content: Work through a grocery list in the produce and dairy sections, compare sale quantities and prices (e.g., carrots 5 for $2 vs. 10 for $3), avoid overbuying, handle fragile items (eggs), and choose cheese types (mozzarella, cheddar, marble). Then weigh movie genre preferences (comedy, romance, action, animated, horror), consider maturity level, and purchase tickets.
keyTopics: genre negotiation (comedy, romance, action, animated, horror)

segments.title: Daily Routines and Healthier Habit Advice (+ Q&A Practice)
segments.content: Analyze an unhealthy daily routine (late nights, skipping breakfast, candy/soda, fast food) and receive practical advice: earlier bedtime, morning routine adjustments, healthy breakfast, packing lunch, and meeting friends at better times. Contrast with a healthy routine (hydration, exercise, meal prep, biking commute). Conclude with Q&A prompts to reinforce comprehension and fluency through repetition.

seriesStructure.seriesTitle: Everyday English in Real Life: Dining, Errands, and Daily Habits
seriesStructure.description: Build practical English skills for common situations. Across three focused episodes, you will plan and complete a dining outing, handle key errands at the library and bank, and manage day-to-day living with coffee orders, smart grocery shopping, and healthier routines. By the end, you’ll confidently ask for help, make transactions, compare options, and discuss habits and preferences.

episodes.title: From Lobby to Table: Planning and Dining Out
episodes.description: Navigate a full dining journey: speak with a hotel concierge to choose and get to a restaurant, get seated, read the menu, and place an order politely and clearly.

episodes.title: Errands That Matter: Library and Bank Confidence
episodes.description: Find and borrow the right book, ask staff for recommendations, discuss genres (including mystery fiction), and complete basic transactions at a bank counter with clarity.

episodes.title: Daily Living: Coffee, Groceries, and Healthy Routines
episodes.description: Order coffee and handle payment and loyalty points, make smart quantity/price decisions at the grocery store, and describe daily routines while giving and accepting advice for healthier habits.

learningPath: From Lobby to Table: Planning and Dining Out
Errands That Matter: Library and Bank Confidence
Daily Living: Coffee, Groceries, and Healthy Routines

grammarPoints.structure: Present Simple for habits, facts, and preferences
grammarPoints.description: Used to talk about routines, general truths, and likes/dislikes.
examples: Do you eat fish?
My wife likes spicy food but I do not.
I prefer short books.
grammarPoints.thaiExplanation: ใช้ช่อง V1 เพื่อบอกนิสัย ข้อเท็จจริง และความชอบ เช่น I like…, She works…, Do you…?
commonMistakes: ลืมเติม s กับประธานเอกพจน์บุรุษที่ 3 (He/She/It) เช่น He like spicy food.
ใช้ Present Continuous แทน Present Simple กับนิสัย เช่น I am liking coffee.
ลืมช่วย do/does ในประโยคคำถาม/ปฏิเสธ เช่น You eat fish?

grammarPoints.description: Describes actions happening now, around now, or temporary situations.
examples: Are you enjoying your stay at our hotel?
My wife and I are having a great time.
What kind of book are you looking for?
grammarPoints.thaiExplanation: ใช้ be + V-ing เพื่อบอกสิ่งที่กำลังเกิดขึ้น/ช่วงเวลานี้ หรือสถานการณ์ชั่วคราว
commonMistakes: ลืมกริยา be (am/is/are) เช่น I going to work.
ใช้รูป be ผิดกับประธาน เช่น She are…
ใช้ Present Continuous กับความชอบถาวร เช่น I am preferring short books.

grammarPoints.description: Use modal + base verb to ask politely, make offers, or ask permission.
examples: Can you recommend a nice restaurant?
May we please have a table for two?
Would you also like to add a salad on the side, sir?
grammarPoints.thaiExplanation: ใช้ can/may/would + V1 ในการขอร้อง เสนอ หรือขออนุญาตอย่างสุภาพ
commonMistakes: ใส่ to หลัง modal เช่น Can you to recommend…
ใช้กริยาช่องผิดหลัง modal เช่น May I ordering…
สลับลำดับคำในคำถาม เช่น You can recommend…?

grammarPoints.description: Would like is more polite/formal than want; both use to + verb for actions.
examples: I would like to order two takeout drinks.
What would you like to order?
I want to deposit a check.
grammarPoints.thaiExplanation: would like สุภาพกว่า want. โครงสร้าง: would like + noun / would like to + V1; want + noun / want to + V1
commonMistakes: ลืม to เช่น I would like order…
ใช้ want ในบริบทที่เป็นทางการมากเกินไป
ซ้ำกริยา เช่น I would like to have to order…

grammarPoints.structure: There is/There are (existence and introducing topics)
grammarPoints.description: Used to say something exists or to introduce new items in conversation.
examples: There is an excellent Japanese restaurant downtown.
There are some spicy dishes and some non-spicy dishes.
Is there anything else that you need?
grammarPoints.thaiExplanation: ใช้บอกว่ามี/มีอยู่: เอกพจน์ใช้ there is, พหูพจน์ใช้ there are
commonMistakes: ใช้ is/are ไม่ตรงกับคำนาม เช่น There is many dishes.
ใช้ have แทน there is/are เช่น There have a restaurant.
ลืม any/anything ในประโยคคำถาม/ปฏิเสธ

grammarPoints.description: Use quantity words and container nouns for amounts with countable/uncountable items.
examples: May we please have a pot of green tea?
Let's grab a bunch of bananas and one bag of apples.
Can you grab one carton of eggs from the shelf?
grammarPoints.thaiExplanation: คำบอกปริมาณและหน่วยบรรจุ เช่น a pot of tea, a bag of apples ใช้ of เชื่อมหน่วยกับสิ่งของ
commonMistakes: ใช้ many กับนามนับไม่ได้ เช่น many milk (ควรใช้ much milk)
ลืม of หลังหน่วย เช่น a bag apples
ทำให้นามนับไม่ได้เป็นพหูพจน์ เช่น milks (ยกเว้นความหมายชนิด/แก้ว)

grammarPoints.structure: Adverbs of frequency and time expressions
grammarPoints.description: Frequency adverbs show how often an action happens; common time phrases show when.
examples: I usually wake up at about 6 o' in the morning.
I sometimes hang out with friends.
I often stop by the store to pick up fresh food for dinner.
grammarPoints.thaiExplanation: คำบอกความถี่ (always, often, usually, sometimes, never) วางก่อนกริยาหลักและหลัง be; วลีเวลาเช่น in the morning, at 10:00
commonMistakes: วางตำแหน่งคำบอกความถี่ผิด เช่น I wake up usually…
สับสน at/in/on สำหรับเวลา เช่น at morning (ควร in the morning)
ใช้สองตัวซ้อนกันเกินจำเป็น เช่น always often

grammarPoints.structure: Question forms (Yes/No, WH-, and with be/modals)
grammarPoints.description: Correct auxiliary usage and word order in questions.
examples: Is this your first time visiting our restaurant?
What kind of food do you and your wife want to eat?
How far is the bus stop from your home?
grammarPoints.thaiExplanation: คำถามใช้อินเวอร์ชัน: be/aux + ประธาน + กริยา; ใช้ do/does กับกริยาทั่วไป และ modal + V1
commonMistakes: ลืม do/does ใน WH- questions เช่น What you want?
ใส่คำช่วยซ้ำ เช่น Do you are…?
ลำดับคำผิด เช่น You are where?

grammarPoints.description: Use should/could for advice; consider + -ing for suggestions; base verb for imperatives.
examples: You should go to bed sooner.
Should we buy 10 carrots instead of five?
Consider asking them to meet you after work.
grammarPoints.thaiExplanation: ให้คำแนะนำ: should/could + V1; consider + V-ing; คำสั่ง/คำแนะนำตรงๆ ใช้กริยาช่อง 1 เช่น Please follow me.
commonMistakes: ใส่ to หลัง should/could เช่น should to go
ลืมเติม -ing หลัง consider เช่น consider ask
ใช้ประโยคคำสั่งไม่ใส่ please ในบริบททางการ ทำให้ไม่สุภาพ

grammarPoints.structure: Future forms: will vs. be going to
grammarPoints.description: Will for instant decisions, offers, promises; be going to for plans/intentions or predictions with evidence.
examples: I will arrange for a taxi to pick you and your wife up at noon.
I will be back with a pot of green tea.
Now you are going to listen to a conversation...
grammarPoints.thaiExplanation: will ใช้เมื่อตัดสินใจ/เสนอทันที; be going to ใช้สำหรับแผนหรือสิ่งที่กำลังจะเกิด
commonMistakes: ลืม verb to be ใน going to เช่น I going to…
ใช้ will ทุกกรณีแม้เป็นแผนที่วางไว้แล้ว
ใช้ปัจจุบันธรรมดาแทนอนาคตโดยไม่ใส่บริบทเวลา

grammarPoints.description: Connects past actions to the present; often used without a specific past time.
examples: I have read them before and I did not find them too interesting.
I have actually never read any of her novels.
The points have been added.
grammarPoints.thaiExplanation: ใช้ have/has + V3 เพื่อบอกประสบการณ์หรือผลลัพธ์ที่มีผลถึงปัจจุบัน ไม่ใช้กับเวลาเฉพาะในอดีต (เช่น yesterday, last year)
commonMistakes: ใช้กับเวลาที่แน่ชัดในอดีต เช่น I have read it last year.
ลืม have/has เช่น She never read… (ควร has never read)
ใช้ V2 แทน V3 เช่น have went

grammarPoints.description: Focuses on the receiver of the action; the doer is unknown or unimportant.
examples: Your PIN was accepted.
Your drinks will be ready in a few minutes.
I believe it is located near the back of the store.
grammarPoints.thaiExplanation: โครงสร้าง be + V3 ใช้เมื่อต้องการเน้นผู้ถูกกระทำ หรือไม่ทราบ/ไม่สำคัญว่าใครทำ
commonMistakes: ลืมกริยา be เช่น Your PIN accepted.
ใช้รูปกริยาผิด (ไม่ใช่ V3) เช่น is locate
ใส่ by-ผู้กระทำโดยไม่จำเป็นในทุกกรณี

grammarPoints.description: Multi-word verbs that change meaning; some are separable with objects.
examples: I can check it out for you now.
…hang out with my friends.
I will arrange for a taxi to pick you and your wife up at noon.
grammarPoints.thaiExplanation: กริยาวลี (verb + คำบุพบท/วิเศษณ์) เช่น check out, hang out, pick up บางตัวคั่นกรรมได้ (pick you up)
commonMistakes: วางกรรมผิดตำแหน่งใน phrasal verb ที่คั่นได้ เช่น pick up you
แปลตรงตัว ทำให้ความหมายผิด
ลืมส่วนประกอบ (particle) เช่น check it

grammarPoints.structure: Prepositions of time and place (at/in/on; to/near/after)
grammarPoints.description: Use correct prepositions with times and locations.
examples: I will arrange for a taxi to pick you and your wife up at noon.
He gets back home after midnight.
Perhaps you can only see your friends on the weekend.
grammarPoints.thaiExplanation: เวลา: at (จุดเวลา) in (เดือน/ช่วงเวลา) on (วัน/วันที่); สถานที่: to (ไปยัง), near (ใกล้), at (จุดเฉพาะ)
commonMistakes: ใช้ at แทน in/on เช่น at the morning (ควร in the morning)
ลืม to กับ go/come เช่น go the store
ใช้ on/in สลับกันกับวันและเดือน

culturalContexts.description: How customers interact with servers and order meals in Western sit-down restaurants.
culturalNotes: Servers often guide you to a table, present menus, offer drinks, and return to take orders.
Menus commonly feature a 'daily special,' and mains may come with soup or salad; salad dressings (e.g., house, ranch) are chosen by the guest.
Guests are expected to state preferences clearly and can ask for recommendations or modifications.
Reservations are common for popular restaurants.
In the US/Canada, tipping (15–20% at sit-down restaurants) is customary.
culturalContexts.thaiContext: Thai restaurants may be less interactive with servers and tipping is not always expected (though service charge may be added in some venues). Side salads and choosing dressings are less central in Thai dining.
practicalTips: Use clear requests: "Could you recommend a non-spicy dish?" "I'd like the daily special with the house dressing, please."
Check local tipping norms before paying.
If you need a reservation, say: "Could I make a reservation for 12:00 noon?"

culturalContexts.description: Concierge staff help guests with local recommendations, reservations, and transport.
culturalNotes: Concierges commonly arrange taxis, book restaurants, and suggest suitable places based on dietary needs.
"Downtown" refers to the city center/business district.
Time precision matters; 'noon' means exactly 12:00 pm.
culturalContexts.thaiContext: Thai hotels offer similar help, but the specific role/title 'concierge' may be more prominent in Western hotels. Tipping concierges is more common in North America than in Thailand.
practicalTips: State needs clearly: "My wife is vegetarian; we prefer non-spicy options."
Carry the destination address to show a taxi/ride-share driver.
Ask: "Do I need a reservation? Could you book it for me?"

culturalContexts.description: Common Western dietary identities and how restaurants respond.
culturalNotes: In Western contexts, 'vegetarian' typically excludes fish; people who eat fish are 'pescatarian.'
Spice levels are often described as mild/medium/hot, and many cuisines offer both spicy and non-spicy options.
Staff routinely ask about allergies and restrictions.
culturalContexts.thaiContext: In Thai contexts, 'mangsaweerat' may still include fish sauce/shrimp paste, while 'jay' excludes all animal products. Clarification is crucial abroad where definitions are strict.
practicalTips: Say: "I'm pescatarian (I eat fish but no other meat)."
Confirm ingredients: "Does this contain fish sauce or shellfish?"
Specify heat: "Mild spice, please."

culturalContexts.topic: Pricing, tax, payment, and loyalty programs
culturalContexts.description: How prices, taxes, and payment methods work in North American-style retail and cafes.
culturalNotes: Displayed prices often do not include sales tax; the final price is higher at checkout.
Customers frequently pay by credit/debit card; contactless is common.
Loyalty programs may add points via a phone number or app; staff may ask for your number at the counter.
culturalContexts.thaiContext: Thailand typically shows final prices inclusive of VAT. Sharing a phone number at checkout is less routine, and loyalty programs are often app-based.
practicalTips: Ask: "Is tax included?" if unsure.
Be ready to enter your PIN and keep your card secure.
If privacy is a concern, show your phone number on your screen rather than saying it loudly.

culturalContexts.description: Ordering customized drinks with various milk and sweetness options.
culturalNotes: Size labels vary (small/medium/large/extra-large); iced drinks are common year-round.
Milk choices include dairy (whole/2%/skim/fat-free) and non-dairy (almond/soy/oat).
Non-dairy choices are often linked to lactose intolerance, vegan diets, or taste; syrups add sweetness/flavor.
culturalContexts.thaiContext: Thai cafes increasingly offer non-dairy milks, but naming and default sweetness can differ; 'less sweet' is a frequent Thai preference.
practicalTips: Order format: "A medium iced vanilla latte with regular milk, less sweet, please."
If dieting, ask for skim milk and minimal syrup.
Clarify: lactose-free dairy is not the same as non-dairy.

culturalContexts.description: How borrowing from libraries differs from buying in bookstores, and social interactions inside stores.
culturalNotes: Libraries lend books free with a library card; due dates (e.g., 3 weeks) apply; renewals may be possible.
Bookstores sell books; staff often have name tags or uniforms.
Casual conversations with other customers are common, but they are not employees.
culturalContexts.thaiContext: Public library use varies in Thailand; bookstores are more familiar. Mistaking a friendly customer for staff can happen in both contexts.
practicalTips: Before asking for help, check: "Excuse me, do you work here?"
Get a library card with ID and proof of address if staying long-term.
Note return deadlines to avoid fines or blocks (policies vary; some libraries have no late fees).

culturalContexts.description: In-person bank transactions and privacy norms.
culturalNotes: Tellers may ask for your bank card and have you enter your PIN into a card reader.
Paper checks are still used and can be deposited at the counter or via ATM/app.
Privacy is expected: shield your PIN; stand a respectful distance behind others in line.
culturalContexts.thaiContext: Thai students often use PromptPay/mobile transfers; paper checks are less common. PIN privacy norms are similar.
practicalTips: Say: "I'd like to deposit a check and check my account balance, please."
Cover the keypad with your hand when entering your PIN.
Bring ID if requested and keep receipts for records.

culturalContexts.topic: Grocery shopping habits and product categories
culturalContexts.description: Supermarket layout, promotions, and common items.
culturalNotes: Stores often start with a produce section; promotions like '5 for $2' encourage bulk buying.
Eggs are treated as fragile and usually refrigerated in North America due to washing practices.
Cheese varieties (cheddar, mozzarella, marble) are common staples.
culturalContexts.thaiContext: Thai supermarkets and wet markets differ; eggs are commonly unrefrigerated in Thailand. Cheese has become more available but remains less central in daily cooking.
practicalTips: Check unit prices to know if a deal is truly cheaper.
Buy only what you can use to reduce waste.
Handle eggs carefully and refrigerate them if required locally.

culturalContexts.topic: Daily routines, wellness, and work culture
culturalContexts.description: Self-improvement focus on sleep, exercise, commuting, and meal prep.
culturalNotes: Morning exercise (running, yoga, weights) and biking to work are common wellness choices in many Western cities.
Packing lunch is seen as healthy and economical; fast food is acknowledged but viewed as less healthy.
Using a 'snooze' button and discussing screen time habits are common lifestyle topics.
culturalContexts.thaiContext: Bangkok traffic, heat, and infrastructure may limit biking; night social life can push bedtimes late. University/work lunch culture varies, often with easy access to street food.
practicalTips: Adopt changes gradually: earlier bedtime, simple packed lunch 2–3 days/week.
Use public transit/bike when safe and practical; check local bike lanes.
Replace sugary morning snacks with fruit, yogurt, or nuts.

culturalContexts.description: Direct yet friendly English interactions with service workers and strangers.
culturalNotes: Frequent use of 'please,' 'thank you,' and friendly phrases like 'sure thing,' 'no problem,' 'have a great day.'
First names are common; 'sir/ma'am' used for politeness in service settings.
Clear, assertive statements of preferences are expected and not considered rude.
culturalContexts.thaiContext: Thai communication often emphasizes indirectness and kreng jai; honorifics/particles (krap/ka) convey politeness. Small talk with strangers may be less direct.
practicalTips: Frame requests clearly: "I'd like X, please" rather than hinting.
Add simple politeness markers and a friendly tone.
Practice brief small talk (weather, weekend plans) to build rapport.
